title.narrative: PoC: Human Security Survey South Sudan

description.narrative: Civilian communities, their local civil society representatives (chiefs, women’s groups, youth groups, religious authorities, etc.), political authorities at the national and local levels, law enforcement and security agencies, across South Sudan. Specific authorities targeted in local level advocacy are payam administrators, county commissioners, state ministers and members of parliament, governors and the traditional (paramount) chiefs who are not politically appointed but chosen by communities themselves and therefore are genuine community leaders, just like religious leaders. In addition, we aim to extend our contacts within the relevant local police ranks and, where possible and constructive, representatives from the national army (SSPDF) and local armed youth (armed cattle keepers). On the national (Juba) level, we hope to engage with the relevant government institutions such as ministries (Internal Affairs, Justice), national members of parliament from the regions we survey, the South Sudan Bureau for Community Security and Small Arms Control, police headquarters, and, where possible and constructive, representatives from national army and security agencies.

The Human Security Survey (HSS) is a flagship research and community engagement methodology developed and implemented by PAX in close coordination with its local partners in Iraq and South Sudan. It combines research, advocacy, and community engagement efforts to amplify the voice of civilians in conflict (the demand side), and to improve the provision of people-centered security in conflict-affected areas (the supply side). The recurrent quantitative research cycles, which are at the core of the project, provide valuable insights into the nature and scope of protection issues facing civilians and how these change over time. These insights are leveraged at the community, national, and international level to make security policies and their implementation more reflective of and responsive to civilian needs, priorities and capacities. At the community level, dialogue sessions enable civilians to influence practical decisions made by local security actors, including military, local government, police, traditional leaders, and non-state armed actors that deeply affect civilians’ day-to-day lives. At the national level, evidence-based advocacy aspires to contribute to more systematic civilian-centered approaches to be adopted by security actors and relevant line ministries, as well as provide the bureaucratic push for change at the community level. At the international level, the HSS provides a means of influencing the policymaking efforts of diplomats and troop contributors active in these environments by providing valuable first-hand information about the realities facing conflict-affected populations. The methodology and our implementing teams are built to be as inclusive and gender-sensitive as possible. The HSS is a continuing initiative that capitalizes on the 2019-2023 PoC program to deepen and expand PAX’s efforts in Iraq and South Sudan as well as internationally. In South Sudan, surveys take place in Central Equatoria, Greater Yirol, Jonglei, Payinjiar, and from 2020 onwards, will expand to include in Eastern Equatoria as well.

The Human Security Survey projects aim to contribute to improvements in the security situation of civilian populations by generating data on local experiences and perceptions of conflict; by facilitating dialogues about local priorities and capacities for security promotion; and by conducting evidence-based advocacy with a wide range of national and international stakeholders. Targeted advocacy efforts seek to enhance the claim-making capacity of civilian populations and help them to hold security actors more accountable for meeting their protection obligations. Similarly, at the international level, advocacy contributes towards improved protection policies and practices for international security actors. This should lead to more people-centered security interventions and, ultimately, to the improved security of civilians in Iraq. Key outcomes of the HSS South Sudan project are: (1) Civilians in conflict improve their human security situation through constructive engagement with (inter)national security actors (long-term outcome); (2) protection policies and practices in South Sudan are increasingly informed by HSS findings (short-term outcome); and (3) community engagement activities inform more relevant protection of civilians strategies in target areas in South Sudan (short-term outcome).

This project is part of the 2019-2023 PoC program and is an expansion of the Human Security Survey South Sudan project (IATI activity identifier NL-KVK-30214009-T35P066) under the 2016-2019 PAX Strategic Partnership.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 19318 3501 DH Utrecht The Netherlands

sector.narrative: Civilian peacebuilding, conflict prevention and resolution

description.narrative: The website of the PAX Protection of Civilians program contains general information about the program and its projects, our latest publications and blog posts, partners, and more.

title.narrative: Dashboard of Human Security Survey South Sudan survey data (English)

description.narrative: This interactive dashboard shows the results of the Human Security Survey (HSS) in South Sudan. Results are presented per survey round and state, and can furthermore be disaggregated by gender. The dashboard consists of five thematic pages, namely demographics, security context & threats, vulnerability, security actors, and future expectations, and a sixth page on methodology.

title.narrative: Dashboard of the PAX PoC Annual Report 2019 – Human Security Survey South Sudan (HSS-SS)

description.narrative: The PAX PoC Annual Report 2019 reflects upon the first reporting period for the Protection of Civilians (PoC) program, initiated in September 2019. This document provides a detailed report for the Human Security Survey South Sudan (HSS-SS) project, including additional analysis as to the key results achieved during the reporting period, complemented by featured stories and further reflections from our partners.

title.narrative: Activity 1.1.2: Human security surveys conducted in South Sudan

description.narrative: Definitions: HSS respondents: Number of respondents after data cleaning, who agree voluntarily to be interviewed by the enumerators, and who agree to their data being used for further analysis.

comment.narrative: Two locations were surveyed in Q4 2020. The respondents for one of these two locations are not included in this tally. The actual value for Q4 will be updated once data cleaning is completed.
No data collection rounds planned for the inception phase.
Target: 2.000-2.500 respondents per year (at least 500 per targeted state).

title.narrative: Activity 1.2.3: Community dialogues with local civilians and relevant authorities organized in South Sudan
# of community dialogues with local civilians and relevant authorities

description.narrative: Definitions: Community dialogues: 3-day meetings facilitated by PAX and partners, organized to inform and consult various groups of local communities, such as local government officials, local security providers and local civil society representatives. The meetings have two main purposes: present the HSS survey data (and receive their feedback), and to discuss among community groups what should be done and prioritized concerning the local security situation. Relevant authorities: Both formal authorities (government officials from state, county or payam level, formal police or army leadership) and informal authorities like (paramount) chiefs and armed youth leaders, etc.

comment.narrative: No community dialogues planned for the inception phase.

title.narrative: Short-term outcome 1.2: Community engagement activities inform more relevant protection of civilians strategies in target areas in South Sudan
# of community engagement activities implemented by community committees

description.narrative: Definitions: Community engagement activities: Follow-up activities that address the action plan discussed and agreed at the community dialogue (e.g. focus group discussions, workshops, public campaigns, radio talk shows, awareness raising events, sports or other cultural activities as part of peacebuilding messages). This does not include the community dialogues themselves or advocacy meetings organized by PAX or partners. Community committees: Groups of volunteers formed by participants from the community dialogues representing various groups and institutions within society, mandated by the community dialogue to address the main community security priorities discussed and agreed in the action plan. These follow-up activities are also known as community engagement activities.

comment.narrative: Target: 3-5 activities per committee per year; five active commitees.
Target: 3-5 activities per committee per year; five active commitees.
